I received clear feedback that improved my learning.

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: learned about neoplatonism
Learned what Neoplatonism was, and how to game the English department into teaching a class that isn't really English (or strictly Renaissance/Medieval_
Neoplatonism through the ages, the mix of philosophy and literature.

Before this course, I had zero idea as to what Neoplatonism is and I had never taken a class with Professor Mohamed. Most of us admitted that we were taking this course to fulfill a Renaissance credit for the English major, and I never had any experience with any kind of philosophical texts either (I came from a high school that didnt really offer us any kind of directed studies education or something like that). I ended the course with a greater appreciation for philosophy, Neoplatonism, and for Professor Mohamed. Hes a wonderful resource in the class, and he is what MAKES this course so accessible and engaging to students like me who struggle with grasping big philosophical concepts.
A thorough understanding of Neoplatonism and how it has impacted the English literary tradition, giving it new motifs and metaphors
Knowledge of the Neoplatonic tradition across the three Abrahamic religions, and preceding. Developed skills associated with writing philosophy papers.
I learned about the history of neoplatonism.
As someone with very little exposure to philosophy, I learned how to read complex philosophical texts with a critical lens. I believe these skills are invaluable

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: excellent course
Great class! Very philosophical, not your classical english class but amazing nonetheless

The biggest strength is Professor Mohamed. Easily one of the best professors Ive ever had during my time at Yale. Hes incredibly kind, understanding, intelligent, and I wish I had gone to more office hours with him because the times that I did go, I had great guidance and I was able to engage more with the course than I could before. There really were no weaknesses, except for the fact that there were some readings that were confusing because of their language. But the great thing was that Professor Mohamed admitted that they were confusing. He was very understanding and he often invited us to ask questions during seminar (and sometimes questions were all that we had during discussions).

The syllabus was difficult to keep track of at times  i would have appreciated more guidance on how to read the texts and would perhaps start with a text like the Mundus Imaginalis so that it was easier to understand what made these texts so interesting. I often felt like I was grasping at straws trying to understand the material and would have appreciated more literature and less philosophy  or at least reading the philosophy alongside the literature. This often felt more like a Philosophy than Literature course. The syllabus definitely needs reworking, but the class has potential!
The course was engaging and generally well taught. Class discussions were very productive, but I felt that too much reading was assigned.

I loved the format of the course: beginning class with contextual information on our authors and sessions facilitated by different students each day. I also thought Professor Mohamed was particularly skilled at interjecting when necessary, but also letting the conversation take its own course when needed. It was a wonderful balance!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: i would recommend this class to anyone
If you need it for the requirement, or are very into neoplatonic philosophy
Yes!
Yes! This is a great class on a very interesting topic

I would highly recommend taking a course with Professor Mohamed. If youre like me and you have little to no familiarity with literary canon before the 1800s, I promise you that you will not find a better guide and professor than Mohamed.
I would! Fascinating subject and it sheds so much light on English literature and philosophy.
If the syllabus was adjusted!
I would recommend this course to any student who wants an introduction to Neoplatonic philosophy, or philosophy in general.
If you need a Renaissance credit, this isnt a bad one to take.
Absolutely! If youre interested in philosophy and are looking for an on-ramp into critical philosophical texts, this class is a wonderfully supportive environment to do so
